Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Postdoctoral Research Fellowship award to Dr. Lindsay Brin is supported by both the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Office of International Science and Engineering at the National Science Foundation. During the 24-month fellowship, Dr. Brin will work on a project titled, "Effects of climate change on winter N cycling and microbial communities in agricultural ecosystems," under the sponsorship of Dr. Claudia Goyer at the Potato Research Centre in Fredericton, New Brunswick, Canada.

This project will investigate the effects of snowfall on the amount of fertilizer nitrogen (N) that is lost from agricultural fields during the winter and the following growing season. This loss can occur through leaching into the groundwater, which harms water quality, or through bacterial conversion to gaseous N or nitrous oxide (N2O), which is a strong greenhouse gas that causes global warming. Climate change may alter snowfall patterns, which could affect soil N cycling. To study these potential effects, Dr. Brin will conduct a 2-year field experiment to examine how snow depth affects N2O production, the amount of N in the soil, and the soil bacteria that produce N2O. She will also conduct a laboratory experiment to examine how snowmelt and refreezing affect soil N processes.

By adding to our knowledge of winter N cycling, this project may help managers in both the United States and Canada improve practices to avoid N losses from agricultural fields. Furthermore, results from this work may be useful for modeling climate change effects and feedbacks. Additionally, this study will involve undergraduate students from the University of New Brunswick, who will learn about soil processes and biogeochemical cycles.

This award provides a unique opportunity for a US scientist to collaborate with foreign scientists, and utilize the unique facilities, expertise and experimental conditions available abroad.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans have massively altered the global nitrogen (N) cycle, largely through the use of synthetic, inorganic N fertilizers. While this invention has sustained the growth of the world’s population, its use has also had detrimental environmental consequences, including substantial emissions of the potent greenhouse gas nitrous oxide (N2O). Of all N2O emissions due to human activities, the majority come from agricultural systems. These emissions occur naturally when N is processed, or cycled, in the soil, and converted by soil microbes into a gaseous form that can be emitted to the atmosphere.  

Surprisingly, up to 80% of these emissions can occur outside the growing season, and recent evidence suggests that nitrogen (N) cycling continues in agricultural soils when temperatures are below freezing. However, these processes and mechanisms, and how they may respond to climate change, are largely understudied. In particular, climate change has the potential to alter snow cover depth and timing, and increase the frequency of winter thawing and snowmelt events, which can alter soil processes. This is because a blanket of snow acts as an insulator on frozen winter soils, keeping soil temperatures around -1ºC, rather than the colder temperatures of the air above the snow. If climate change brings periods of warmth during winter, snow will melt and the soil will be less insulated when air temperatures once again drop below freezing. Alternatively, if climate change brings increased precipitation, this could increase snow depths and stabilize soil temperatures. Such changes in soil temperature and moisture can alter N cycling, along with the communities of soil microbes that carry out N cycling processes, potentially resulting in changes in greenhouse gas emissions from soils.

To assess how changes in winter climate may affect N losses from agricultural soils, this project investigated the effect of variation in snow cover and snowmelt on soil N, gaseous N emissions, N cycling processes, and gene abundance, expression, and diversity of microbes that mediate these processes, i.e. nitrifiers and denitrifiers. The effect of snow depth was investigated through a 2-year field study in which snow was removed, passively increased through the use of snow fences, and left at ambient heights. The study was carried out in Fredericton, New Brunswick, Canada, at a site representative of seasonally snow-covered North American agricultural lands. To further examine the soil mechanisms affecting N cycling during winter thaw and snowmelt events, a laboratory microcosm experiment was conducted that examined the effects of increased temperature and/or moisture on soil N cycling, including N2O production, soil nutrients, and denitrifier and nitrifier gene abundance and expression.

The field study demonstrated that as denitrification continues during winter, N2O gas accumulates in frozen soils. This N2O is then released during spring thaw, along with gas that is actively being produced in the soil. In the first year of the study, soils on which snow had been removed had the greatest accumulation of N2O during winter and the greatest N2O emissions during thaw, suggesting that in future winters with decreased snow, bare soils could cause a positive climate change feedback via greater N2O production. However, in the second year of the study, much greater winter soil accumulation and spring thaw emissions of N2O were observed for soils with the most consistent snow coverage.
